title: Dozens walk in memory of Seaforde Special Olympian
story: UPWARDS of  people took part in a charity walk around Castlewellan Lake on Saturday in memory of Seaforde man Glenn McBride, who died  weeks ago.Glennwas a medalled Special Olympics competitor who enjoyed soccer and basketball, playing both to a high standard.He was a popular member of of Down Special Olympics Club in Downpatrick and Shimna Stars Special Olympics Club in Newcastle.Glenn won a soccer gold medal with Team Down at the Area Games in Belfast in  and was a member of the Ulster soccer team at the Ireland Games the following year. He won a basketball gold medal with Team Ulster at the Ireland Games in .His friend Harry Walsh organised the walk in aid of the Belfast Cancer Centre to honour Glennrsquos commitment to the people who looked after him so well when he was ill.While Glenn had originally wanted to host a charity football match, he suggested a sponsored walk instead as it would be more Covid-aware.He never got the chance to host the walk but Harry continued it with it in his memory.Harry described his friend as having ldquothe kindest heart and soul who was always considerate to others.ldquoHe was never judgemental, and his passing has shown what a fantastic inspirational friend he was to many, he wrote on Facebook.ldquoHis passing is a huge loss and has left a massive hole in the lives of his family, his friends, me personally and this world in general..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C May 30%2C 2011
story: DOWNPATRICK mdash Down District could be in line for a multi-million pound investment package which has the potential to create several hundred new jobs.Private talks between a number of key players in the financial and construction industries have been taking place over the past number of months and a major announcement is expected shortly.The core of the talks focused on Downpatrickrsquos poundm business park and an investment package of several million pounds has been put together to unlock its huge potential.It has emerged that plans are at an advanced stage to build a number of purpose built units at a -acre site at the Belfast Road complex to entice major companies to set up businesses in the area.The plan is to have business units in place to ensure that when investors do express an interest in coming to the area, they can move in almost immediately.One of the key men involved in the talks is local councillor Harvey Bicker and he has no doubt the amount of finance which has been put together can pave the way for ldquountold opportunities in the area.He has been able to secure the support of major financial players who have already agreed with the IDB to build the so-called advance factories at the Downpatrick business park.It is understood one major company is already interested in relocating its business to the Belfast Road site and several others are also believed to have expressed an interest in the -acre complex.NEWCASTLE mdash A teacher at Shimna Integrated College in Newcastle has this week discovered she is in a class of her own.A favourite amongst pupils, work colleagues and parents, Karen Caulfield, head of maths at the college, has been shortlisted for the prestigious Teacher of the Year award.The Rostrevor woman had been secretly nominated by several teaching colleagues and by parents of her students.According to school principal Kevin Lambe, Mrs Caulfieldrsquos colleagues entered her for the award as they were so impressed by her leadership qualities, her ability to inspire students, her innovative work and her organisation of the schoolrsquos numeracy strategy.ldquoMrs Caulfield is a wonderful teacher and a real asset to our college. Her colleagues all say that she has a real gt for helping students have confidence in their own ability, he said.KILLYLEAGH mdash The charred remains of Killyleagh GAA club, gutted in a blaze in the early hours of Monday morning, are to be demolished.The fire completely engulfed the clubhouse at Wolfe Tone Park, and it has been decided by club and Down County Board officials to demolish the clubhouse instead of refurbishing it.The building has been lying vacant since last year after the Wolfe Tone Club encountered financial dficulties and its teams were withdrawn from the Down leagues.The blaze, which spelled the final fate of the building, took place in the early hours of Monday morning.Downpatrick fire crews were alerted shortly after am and on arrival at the scene had to call for assistance from Ballynahinch and Comber to help control the flames.It took firemen more than four hours to bring the fire under control and by am on Monday morning all that was left of the vacant building was a crumbling shell and an acrid smell of hot ash.BALLYNAHINCH mdash A Ballynahinch student is flying high after gaining his private pilotrsquos licence.After months of gruelling training Phillip Miskimminrsquos dream of piloting a plane for a prestigious airline and travelling the world is well within his reach.As most  year-olds hop into the seat of a car, Phillip is now able to jump into the cockpit of a light aircraft, but the ambitious high-flyer is not going to settle at that.He is determined to one day become a flight captain for a commercial airline, flying passengers to destinations across the globe.Phillip was trained for his private pilotrsquos licence at Aldergrove Airport and was funded by a scholarship which he won from the Guild of Air Pilots and Navigators.The successful teenager was also the winner of the John Landymore trophy which is awarded to the most outstanding scholarship winner.Currently an aeronautical engineering student at Queenrsquos University, the former pupil of St Patrickrsquos Grammar School in Downpatrick has the world at his feet.The young pilot has had a passion for flying since he was  and is thrilled that he can now actually fly an aircraft.KILLOUGH mdash Raised from the ashes by the local community, Killough Hall once again stands proudly in the heart of the village.Local people, young and old, flocked to the newly built youth and community centre at Palatine Square to celebrate itrsquos official opening on Friday, four years after an overnight fire left it completely gutted.In an admirable community drive local people have resurrected the building which had been part of the local village for generations.Well known author historian and Killough native, Dr Maurice Hayes, officially unveiled the new centre which will provide leisure facilities, further education courses and a social venue for all.Reminiscing about his childhood days when he used to go to the hall every Saturday afternoon for his ldquohated dance classes, a jovial Dr Hayes said it was wonderful that the hall has been restored.Mr Hayes said everyone who worked so hard to get the hall back on its feet have helped bring a new heart and le into the building and a new heart and le into Killough.STRANGFORD ndash Bank Holiday Monday was a busy day for local RNLI and Coastguard members, with two call-outs off the County Down coastline.The first incident took place at around .pm in Strangford Lough when a sailing dinghy, with three men onboard, capsized close to The Long Sheelagh rock.One of the men was rescued by a passing fishing vessel while the others were clinging to the boatrsquos hull when Portaferry leboat arrived. A Wessex helicopter from RAF Aldergrove joined the rescue and members of Portaferry Coastguard were called to assist.ldquoAll three casualties were winched to the helicopter and taken to shore close to Kircubbin Sailing Club. None of the men, who were wearing wet suits and le jackets, were seriously injured and it is believed adverse weather conditions caused the boat to overturn, said a Coastguard spokeswoman.As this incident was closing and the helicopter had just landed the casualties, Coastguards then received information that two young boys were being blown offshore in a small boat close to Ballyhornan.ldquoThe helicopter was re-tasked and itrsquos crew stood by with members of the Ardglass Coastguard unit, but the children, who were aged  and , were able to make it back to shore safely, she added.SAINTFIELD ndash Teenagers in Saintfield are being blamed for vandalising stone walls and blocking a river in the town.Concerned residents in Shrewsbury Dale have voiced their concern about what is happening and asked local councillor Robert Burgess to address the problem.Mr Burgess said residents and local farmers are becoming increasingly concerned at the behaviour of the teenagers and highlighted the importance of making them realise the error of their ways.He explained that over the past number of months, children have punched holes in local hedgerows to gain access to fields adjacent to the Shrews-bury Dale housing development.ldquoLivestock and horses have been in the fields concerned and we have to be thankful they did not escape as a result of the childrenrsquos action, Mr Burgess continued..prettyPhoto

title: New £50k play park at Downpatrick school
story: A DOWNPATRICK primary school has officially opened its new pound, playground and garden facilities.St Colmcillersquos Primary School in Glebetown Drive now has a new sensory garden called the Rainbow garden, an outdoor play park and a new welcome garden at the schoolrsquos front door.School principal Stephen Austin said the facilities were financed by pound, raised by the careful management of the school budget and pound, from the schoolrsquos Parents, Teachers and Friends Association .Planns were drawn up last June and the work by contractor, All Play Ballynahinch, began in January.Mr Austin explained: ldquoThe school is set on a spacious site with several large green areas.ldquoI wanted to maximise the learning potential of our school site to improve pupils holistic learning experiences, particularly within the areas of outdoor education, activity based and play based learning which are essential areas of the curriculum and so important in eliciting enthusiasm in learning and developing key skills in core areas such as literacy, numeracy, ICT and STEAM.ldquoI also wanted to enhance facilities for our wonderful children who deserve the best and who were disadvantaged by interruptions to their schooling in recent times due to the Covid pandemic. But also to strengthen school community and pride in our fantastic school.Mr Austin paid tribute to the schools PTFA for its fundraising, to the board of governors for support and a group of volunteers who worked on the welcome garden.ldquoThe team spirit that has been displayed throughout this project has been uplting and a reflection of the strong school community that exists within St Colmcilles Primary School, he said.ldquoThe board of governors have supported this project throughout and are committed to a cycle of continuous improvement of all aspects of the school, especially its facilities and resourcesHe continued: ldquoThe PTFA have fundraised relentlessly through organising ious raffles, draws, bingos and hampers. They have enjoyed amazing support from our parents and the whole school community who all have been very generous. So far, they have contributed pound, to the project which has allowed us to go the extra mile with more extensive resources and a very high spec finish in the ious areas.He said that the welcome garden was created almost exclusively by volunteers such as grandparent Stephen Vaughan, who built the planter boxes, the garden furniture was designed and constructed by brothers Lawrence and Gareth Blaney, the circular stone planter built by parent Fergus Rooney , grounds work was carried out by Pascal Magee and planting by Bill Carew. Plants and shrubs were provided at a discounted rate from Cunningham Flowers in Dundrum.The schoolrsquos head of outdoor education, Sean McReynolds, oversaw the project with building supervisors Brian Tweedie and Bill Carew, classroom assistant Ryan Craig and Gemma Vaughan, the schoolrsquos eco co-ordinator.Parent Roisin McKenna, who along with Andrea McMenamin, Natasha Shields and Rosaleen Cunlfe leads the PTFA committee, said that they had enjoyed ldquoamazing support from parents, the wider school community and local businesses.Roisin said: ldquoThe ethos of our PTFA is about "making memories" and this is always at the forefront of our fundraising. We wanted the money we raised to benefit every child in the school and therefore the school have all the children timetabled for outdoor learning everyday.ldquoThis makes our fundraising all worthwhile when you see happy children playing daily outdoors.The PTFA organised fundraising initiatives like bingo, raffles, hampers and draws which have allowed the school to further develop the footprint of the planned facilities for the children.The schoolrsquos Rainbow garden includes a tepee, a water wall for directing and controlling the flow of water, an activity table, a water and sand tray, outdoor shelter, sensory plants with a vivid colour or smell and plastic coated activity table where children can paint use sand and textiles to show their learning.Therersquos also an outdoor classroom which can hold up to  pupils and adults with bespoke seating and a blackboard with outdoor musical equipment.Itrsquos contained within ranch style fencing and is very popular with all the schoolrsquos pupils, particularly those within its learning support centres, many of whom have complex sensory needs.The new play park contains swings, slide, climbing tower, monkey bars, balance equipment, ropes, seesaws seating and planting areas.Children are timetabled at break and lunch times and for certain lessons throughout the day.An eye-catching circular stone planter has been filled with a iety of shrubs and trees in the new Welcome garden.Therersquos also a bespoke reading area overlooking four large rectangular sleeper planter boxes filled with beautul summer flowers, a solar powered water fountain, a bird bath and bird tables..prettyPhoto

title: Politicians gather to mark Northern Ireland centenary
story: CROSSGAR marked Northern Irelandrsquos centenary on Monday with a special event.A number of local politicians including South Down MLA Harry Harvey and Rowallane councillors Billy Walker, Terry Andrews, Robert Burgess and Kathryn Owen met in the village square with each holding a torch which symbolised what happened in Crossgar a century ago when the province was formed.On that occasion, a bonfire was lit in the square by local residents to celebrate the creation of Northern Ireland on election night of the new parliament.The local MP was Sir James Craig, the first Prime Minister of Northern Ireland who had personal ties to Crossgar and had been its Westminster MP since .To mark the national and local event, local politicians from all parties were invited to hold a flame in a triangular shape on Monday symbolising the fire that was lit on the birth of the country in .Cllr Walker said he was delighted to have been invited to Crossgar to take part in the special event to mark Northern Irelandrsquos th birthday..prettyPhoto

title: Tributes paid to Down Rec soccer legend Jim Connolly
story: JIM Connolly died on April  after a hard fought two year battle with illness.His passing was marked by a phenomenal level of tributes.Social media,work colleagues, team-mates and opponents alike expressed how well liked and respected he was in all walks of le.He was first and last a family man whether it was his brothers and sisters, Angie and his children or his beloved grandchildren.However Coot, as he was known, had another family which he held dear. He had been a vital cog in the Down Rec team which enjoyed great success in the late Seventies.But it was and remains the case that the Down Rec experience is defined by the enduring friendships which have stood the test of time.Coot grew up in Stream Street and the reason he knocked back opportunities to perform at levels his talent merited may well lie there.That part of Downpatrick had three working class housing developments, Ardpatrick and Russell Park with Stream Street and Ibrox Park in the middle.Ibrox was their playground, the place where Coot first kicked a football.He was a Stream Street kid and it seems he never wanted to be anything .When Jim Prior took him to Down Rec, it was a marriage made in heaven.In that dressing room you had another more senior Stream Street kid. Coot would have idolized Tony lsquoDartrsquo Curran in those days as he was the leader of the pack.Russell Park resident Barney Fitzsimmons was there too, a swashbuckling goalscorer who enjoyed something akin to Roy of the Rovers status at the time.Then you had the late great Paddy lsquoGeordyrsquo Galbraith, who combined a hard man reputation with a heart of gold.Peter Mulhall was another player he would have admired, a winner who proved the perfect centre back partner for the laid-back Coot.The total respect he had for them was accorded to all of us even though he was a better player than any of us. That was Coot Connolly.Prior realized that he needed to recruit from outside Downpatrick to fulfill his ambitions for the club and over a period of time he recruited players from Portaferry, Strangford, Ardglass, Dundrum, Crossgar, Saintfield, Killyleagh and Ballygowan.They were brought in for their ability but Jim couldnrsquot have known that the erse personalities therein would create the perfect storm in the dressing room.Neither could he have anticipated the level of support which flowed from those villages in the seasons to come.Dressing rooms are bastions of banter and slagging and with Dart jester-in chief, the group relished every minute they spent together.The five strong Portaferry contingent proved to be a vital ingredient, their earthy Ards humour and the opportunities their accents provided for slagging sealing their popularity.Jackie Leckey and Barney Ross brought another dimension willing as they were to join in the shenanigans on and off the pitch. Coot loved the craic and happily joined in the banter.However, he left the slagging to other less sensitive creatures of which there were plenty.A good example was the time I decided to get the footballers perm which was in vogue at the time. I should have known better.I got slaughtered, Dart declaring that I looked more like Shirley Temple than Kevin Keegan.Those were the days, as the saying goes, but happily there were plenty of good days ahead of us.We have had many reunions with Coot, an ever present and every one of them underlined the strength of the bond we enjoy so much.Sadly those reunions tend to be confined to wakes and funerals nowadays and the baby of our team has now joined Shane Breen, Paddy Galbraith and Marty Ross on the sidelines.Coot would have been the first to remind me that the Rec wasnrsquot only about the players.The one and only Charlie Oakes was highly influential in his role as assistant manager, while Austy Keating doubled as chairman and groundsman for many years.Joe Lyttle was our physio and his son Joea loyal player for years while my sister Tina was a committee member and a fanatical fan.They were all fully paid up members of the Rec family and we continue to mourn their loss.I would love to have name checked every single member of the Rec family in this piece but time and space didnrsquot allow. My apologies.The laughter which rang through Cootrsquos house during his wake was a fitting farewell for someone who loved to laugh.He was a very special human being. We will miss him forever. Rest in peace mate..prettyPhoto

story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. title: unionism can both have a wide range of views on non constituional issues while also uniting against the irish sea border
story: DUP’s isions now in full view as party members publicly slug it out over Arlene Foster’s ousting   DUP in crisis - PSNI receive complaint that DUP members were allegedly threatened and intimidated by UDANewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedHome and GardenTechnologyFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesNewsOpinionUnionism can both have a wide range of views on non constitutional issues while also uniting against the Irish Sea borderNews Letter editorial of Friday may  :By EditorialFriday, th May , : amUpdated Friday, th May , : pm  "       "  ]]News Letter editorialThere are now three main leaders of unionism in Northern Ireland.Edwin Poots leads what is still, despite an apparent poll dip, the larget unionist party, the DUP.Doug Beatie leads the Ulster Unionist Party, which dominated NI politics for its first  years, but is now much diminished.    " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...And Jim Allister QC is at the helm of Traditional Unionist Voice, which is much smaller than the DUP or UUP, but is led by a man who is respected across unionism and who polls far better as an inidual than his party does.This is a crowded field for a unionism that has seen its overall vote shrink since . It is hard to see how a three-way split can be sustained, yet there is a case for two main unionist blocs — a moderate one and a conservative one.There is an increasing view that a single unionist party would just drive more voters to the neutral political centre.The biggest issue by far facing unionism is the NI Protocol Boris Johnson betrayal. Senior DUP politicians have seemed far too willing to accept tough talk from Tories such as Lord Frost. Yet London keeps reiterating its commitment to the protocol, about which Brussels is so uncompromising. The UK says the Act of Union has been partially repealed and we must assume that is the situation . It is an outrage, yet Edwin Poots has to date been pragmatic about this Irish Sea border. Doug Beattie yesterday seemed to say on radio that the protocol was less important than the NHS, but the comparison is misleading because it is an utterly dferent policy area. It is possible both to think that health is the single most important non constitutional matter, but that the constitutional question is the single most important political issue.That is what republicans think, yet they do not allow themselves to be talked into saying the NHS is more important.A united unionist rejection of the repeal of the Act of Union can, and should, exist alongside a wide range of views among unionists on non constitutional matters.——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: new dup leader edwin poots denies party is divided
story: Huge fireball spotted in NI night sky was like something from the film Armageddon   Arlene Foster awarded six figure sum in damages from TV presenter Dr. Christian JessenNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedHome and GardenTechnologyFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesNewsPoliticsNew DUP leader Edwin Poots denies party is idedThe Stormont Agriculture Minister was ratied by his party following a stormy meeting at a Belfast hotel on Thursday night.By Rebecca Black and James Ward, PAFriday, th May , : amUpdated Friday, th May , : am  "       "  Outgoing leader Arlene Foster and several senior figures including Sir Jeffrey Donaldson, Gavin Robinson and Diane Dodds left the building before Mr Poots rose to give his speech.Paul Bell, a DUP member of  years from Mrs Foster’s Fermanagh and South Tyrone constituency, dramatically resigned from the party over its treatment of her.He hit out at those who ousted Mrs Foster, and warned the party stands to lose thousands of votes at the next election.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...]]Edwin Poots speaks to the media, after leaving the Crowne Plaza Hotel, Belfast on the evening he was ratied as the new DUP leader“This is going to be a real problem for the DUP. The votes that are going to be shed by the DUP is not in their hundreds, it’s in their thousands. It’s in their tens of thousands,” he said.“We cannot go round the doors, the people in Fermanagh and South Tyrone will vote for anyone but the DUP. That is because, not of an election, that is because of what took place before the election.”Mr Poots later addressed the media alongside the newly ratied deputy leader Paula Bradley, with supporters gathered behind him.He described the meeting as “good” and said it is a “great privilege” to now lead the party that his father had helped form  years ago.Mr Poots said there had been a debate and a contest, and that the contest “had been decided”.“We will move forward in a united way,” he said.“The DUP is not a ided party, the DUP has went through an electoral contest, the first in  years, and everybody that goes through an electoral contest will have some passion, and passion is good in politics.“I like to see people having passion, sometimes even when they are people contesting with me. I like to see people who are passionate in their arguments.”Mr Poots added that he hoped to be able to speak to Mr Bell “in the near future”.“Sometimes people don’t like the outcome and they do things in the heat of the moment, I have a lot of respect for the gentleman,” he said.Mr Poots narrowly defeated Sir Jeffrey Donaldson earlier this month in the party’s first leadership contest.In a speech following his ratication, he vowed to revive unionism and scrap the Northern Ireland Protocol.“We will consistently roll back the objectional provisions of the Protocol, as we have been doing,” he said.“That involves arguing our case forcefully and with conviction. It involves making Brussels and Dublin aware that the Protocol is intolerable and unworkable.“Legal challenges are one correct tactic, but the guaranteed way of reading our sales of the isive Protocol is through the Assembly.”He added: “We will employ political tactics to continue the pressure, and let Dublin see that isn’t some hiccup, but rather something that has the worrying capacity to destabilise relationships that they have gained most from.”Mr Poots said his challenge was to encourage supporters of unionism to get out and vote.He also called for a “united unionist coalition” ahead of the next Assembly elections.Mr Poots said the only way of preventing a border poll and getting rid of the Protocol was by securing a Unionist majority at the next election.In his speech, Mr Poots paid tribute to Ms Foster’s leadership of the party.He said: “Arlene is and will be regarded as one of the most foremost women and unionists in British politics.“Irrespective of our dferences in any issues that have brought us here this evening, she is admired by us all.”Mrs Foster announced her resignation as First Minister and DUP leader last month following an internal revolt against her leadership.She said she would step down as DUP leader on Friday and as First Minister at the end of June.Earlier this week, Mrs Foster said she still had not seen the reported letter of no confidence in her leadership.DUP MP Ian Paisley said he understands the party chairman Lord Morrow has read the letter to her and told her the names who signed it.“The process that the party has always adopted is that those letters are not shared with other people who have gone,” he said.“My father never ever saw the requisition order that was signed against him. He accepted it because he accepted the good grace and standing of our party chairman.”Mr Poots has signalled that he will become the first DUP leader not to take the First Minister position at Stormont, and will instead nominate a colleague in order to focus on the job of leading the party.MLAs Mervyn Storey and Paul Givan are reportedly being considered for the post. title: meet penarth man designed new town parklets

title: covid  indian variant hotspots uk revealed
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. are concerns the Indian iant could see cases jump back up.Data from Public Health Englandshows a rise in cases from  to , this week in the UK, with the agency saying cases were ldquorising in the community and it was assessing the impact and severity of the iant.One response being considered is bringing forward the date for a second dose of vaccine for eligible groups to increase protection.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the situation was being monitored carefully and the Government ldquowill not hesitate to take further actionnecessary.However, a small number of areas are seeing a rise in cases as the India iant spreads across the UK.The Prime Minister has said there is "increasing concern" about the iant and warned the emergence of further new iants "pose a potentially lethal danger".Where is the India iant dominant Surge testing has been under way in parts of Bolton since  May, after Public Health Englandconfirmed the town is one of the main locations of the India iant, which was reclassied as a lsquoiant of concernrsquo last week.Cases of the iant in England increased from  to  as of  May, according to PHE figures, with almost half of these related to travel or contact with a traveller.The majority of cases of the India Covid strain are concentrated in the north-west of England, predominantly in Bolton, and in London.The iant is also thought to be the reason behind half of coronavirus infections in Bedford, Blackburn with Darwen and South Northamptonshire, although these outbreaks are still small.Greater Manchester Mayor Andy Burnham has submitted a request to the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation that all over-s in Bolton, along with the rest of the Greater Manchester area, are able to receive a Covid- vaccination ldquoto mitigate the risks of spread in those communities where we are seeing more transmission.     There are also around  to  cases of the India iant in parts of Scotland, including Glasgow, with these cases again connected to travel.The India Covid iant, officially known as B.., was first detected in India in October.It has been designated a ldquoiant of concern by PHE as it is thought to be at least as transmissible as the iant detected in Kent last year, known as B, which is now dominant in the UK.PHE said there is currently no evidence to suggest that the new Indian iant is more serious than previous mutations, nor is there evidence which indicates that this version of the Indian iant is resistant to current vaccines.Health experts said they ldquohavenrsquot seen any hint of a current Covid iant that can fully evade the effectiveness of vaccines.On Wednesday , the European Medicines Agency said it was ldquopretty confident that vaccines currently in use will be effective against the Indian iant, a view that has been echoed by some British scientists.However, Professor James Naismith from the University of Oxford said not enough is known to say for sure whether the iant could frustrate the UKrsquos vaccination programme.Speaking on BBC Radio rsquos Today programme, he said: ldquoThe vaccines donrsquot  per cent prevent infection for people.ldquoWhat they do is, they almost  per cent prevent hospitalisation and serious illness.ldquoWe donrsquot know enough to know yet whether the Indian strain will behave dferently than that.ldquoSo even the regular virus can infect people who have been vaccinated and sometimes you do get reinfection.Could the iant delay lockdown ending The growing number of India Covid iant cases in the UK has sparked concerns that the lting of lockdown restrictions, which is set for  June in England, could now be delayed.Ministers have also not ruled out re-introducing local lockdowns in areas where the iant of concern is increasing.Foreign Office minister James Cleverly said that the government will make decisions based on the data, and measures will be eased ldquoat a pace and in a way which is safe.Symptoms to look forThe main symptoms of coronavirus to look for include:a high temperature ndash this means you feel hot to touch on your chest or back a new, continuous cough ndash this means coughing a lot for more than an hour, or three or more coughing episodes in  hours a loss or change to your sense of smell or taste ndash this means youve noticed you cannot smell or taste anything, or things smell or taste dferent to normalMost people with symptoms have at least one of these symptoms, although some do not experience any. title: jane hutt  senedd win next five years
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. She is the only MS to have served as a Minister in every Welsh Government to date.Ms Hutt ndash who was a South Glamorgan County councillor for  years before first obtaining her Senedd seat in  ndash said: ldquoIt was a lovely outcome ndash itrsquos humbling that people have put their trust in me and Irsquom very grateful.ldquoItrsquos an honour to serve people for the next five years. Therersquos so much to do and Irsquom hitting the ground running.MS Hutt has campaigned for equality for many years she became the first National Co-ordinator of Welsh Womenrsquos Aid in  and was a founder of South Glamorgan Womenrsquos Workshop.ldquoI want safety for all people ndash men and women, said Ms Hutt, who has recently had meetings with Vale of Glamorgan councillors and other agencies about how to make all areas safe for people.Ms Hutt had engaged with Vale of Glamorgan residents throughout her years as an MS, with the coronavirus pandemic and effects of lockdown a concern for the community over the last year,ldquoItrsquos a very dficult time for people, said Ms Hutt."Irsquove been fortunate to serve in First Minister Mark Drakefordrsquos cabinet... and his approach is based on team-work and evidence - not just medical or clinical, but social."Every step of the journey Irsquove focused on the impact [of Covid] on communities, including BAME communities and those with disabilities.ldquoDetrimental issues affecting the community and the people within it are at the fore-front, but I also work with police and the PCC. We have regular discussions about the impact of Covid, and lockdowns, and the easing of restrictions.ldquoIrsquove been engaging with police and Vale of Glamorgan Council enforcement officers to protect our communities and encourage respectful visits to our beautul coasts.     Ms Hutt is also supportive of business lsquoboth large and smallrsquo ndash and has also shown her support for Barry Hospital - in  she campaigned against a planned closure of the -bed Sam Davies Ward at Barry Hospital.ldquoBarry Hospital does wonderful work," said Ms Hutt.The Sam Davies ward played an important role in the Covid pandemic and will continue to do so.Ms Hutt also praised volunteers in the Vale of Glamorgan - and across Wales - for the tremendous support theyve shown within their communities. Earlier this year she thanked a number of volunteers, including Cowbridge Male Voice Choir, for their efforts throughout the coronavirus pandemic.Ms Hutt also engages with young people and supported The Schools CouncilsRegulations  which meant all schools in Wales need a council, enabling pupils to discuss matters relating to school, education, or other areas of concern, and to make representations on these to the governing body and the head teacher."This has helped pupils interest in being citizens and engaging with politics," said Ms Hutt.During the Senedd  election - for the first time - people aged  and  were given the option to vote."It was lovely to meet families who has discusses parties and their manestos," said Ms Hutt."Many of the young people I spoke to had made up their minds [about who to vote for]. Im glad young people felt empowered. Theyve been very much focused on the impact of the pandemic, but theyre also looking out for parents and grandparents generations in a caring way."To the young people who went to their polling stations [to vote] thank you for taking initiative - we will move Wales forward."People have put their trust in me and I will continue to serve all people across all areas of the Vale of Glamorgan." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. Julie Hesmonhalgh, Laura Fraser, Eiry Thomas in Heledd Gwyn in The Pact. Picture: PA Photo BBC Little Door  Warren Orchard." alt"Penarth Times:Julie Hesmonhalgh, Laura Fraser, Eiry Thomas in Heledd Gwyn in The Pact. Picture: PA Photo BBC Little Door  Warren Orchard." class"editor-image" Julie Hesmonhalgh, Laura Fraser, Eiry Thomas in Heledd Gwyn in The Pact. Picture: PA Photo BBC Little Door  Warren Orchard.The Pact follows a group of work friends in the aftermath of the sudden death of their young brewery boss.Bound by a secret that will change their lives forever, they are drawn into a fragile pact of silence ndash but can they all cope with the web of lies that is forming Fraser ndash known for Breaking Bad, Traces and Better Call Saul ndash plays Anna, whose marriage comes under extreme pressure due to the pact with her friends.Her husband Maxis a police officer investigating the shocking death while being completely unaware that his we is linked to the case.:ldquoTheir lives are changed forever, Fraser said. ldquoThings start to spiral out of control, and Irsquom very interested in things spiralling out of control and exploring living in constant fear. I found that all very interesting.The filming location for the characters workplace was Rhymney Brewery, while other scenes in The Pact were filmed in Newport, Monmouth, Usk, Pontypool, and Merthyr Tydfil.Other key scenes were shot in woodlands near Pontsticill Reservoir, near Merthyr.      Warren Orchard.BBC handout " alt"Penarth Times: Rakie Ayola and Jason Hughes in The Pact. Picture: PA Photo BBC Little Door  Warren Orchard.BBC handout " class"editor-image"Rakie Ayola and Jason Hughes in The Pact. Picture: PA Photo BBC Little Door  Warren Orchard.BBC handout ldquoIt felt like a massive privilege to be able to be working during the pandemic, and also working in such a beautul place, said Hesmondhalghndash best known for playing Hayley Cropper in Coronation Street ndash and who portrays Nancy in the new show.ldquoWe were based in Cardf, which is a city I absolutely have fallen in love with completely," she added. "But all the dferent places we went to and filmed were just astonishing.ldquoIt was a really amazing experience and, like all experiences, it sometimes takes you stepping away to realise how lucky you were to do it, because when yoursquore working, yoursquore just in it and doing it.Rakie Ayola, the Noughts and Crosses star from Cardf who plays lead investigator Detective Superintendent Holland in The Pact, said it was an eye-opening experience to film around South East Wales.She said: ldquoEvery time I was on set, I was just saying out loud, lsquoWhy have I never come in this direction from Cardf rsquo Irsquod never gone north for an hour. So, it was like a dferent country to me, and it made me quite sad Irsquod never gone there before. So beautul.While the show was made over an "extremely challenging" few months during the coronavirus public health emergency, its creator McTighe said it was important the drama "provided some relief from the pandemic we are all living through, but it didnrsquot feel right to ignore what wersquove all experienced this past year".The Pact is set slightly in the future"where most of the population is vaccinated and le is ing to lsquonormalrsquo...[but]the stress and anxiety of  and the ious lockdowns has cast a psychological shadow that informs some of [the characters] behaviour and decisions," he said.bull The Pactwill air on BBC One on Mondays and Tuesdays, with the first episode tonightat pm. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityHedgehogs travel around one mile every night through our parks and gardens in their quest to find food and other hogs to mate with. If you have an enclosed garden you might be getting in the way of their plans.One of the main reasons why hedgehogs are declining in Britain is because our fences and walls are becoming more and more secure, reducing the amount of land available to them.Penarth Hedgehog Street will help to connect gardens allowing hedgehogs more space to breed, find food and keep them off the roads. This will form part of the national Hedgehog Street campaign.The project street map for the Penarth estate taking part in the schemeAs part of the project, residents will be able to borrow footprint tracking tunnels and camera traps to monitor and record the presence of hedgehogs.Emily Shaw, the Local Nature Partnership Co-ordinator for the Vale of Glamorgan, said the mission is to reconnect people in the Vale with nature.MORE NEWS:ldquoThe way we will do this is by developing a nature recovery network with partners, where we hope to engage the public, local community groups and organisations, as well as schools and businesses to take part in practical action for nature in their communities, she added.ldquoThe Valersquos LNP is one of several across Wales with each county hosting their own LNP and is part of a fantastic network through a project called LNP Cymru which is co-ordinated by the WCVA and funded by the Welsh Government.As part of Hedgehog Awareness Week, the Vale Local Nature Partnership has launched a new pilot hedgehog highways scheme on a residential estate in Penarth to encourage residents to create small holes in their fences to help hedgehogs move around more easily.     Residents will also be able to get involved in a citizen science project to help us gather data on Penarthrsquos local hedgehog populations.A free online talk is being held on Thursday, May , with Stephen Powles who set up a similar scheme in a small village in Oxfordshire.For more information head to https:www.eventbrite e creating-hedgehog-highways-in-the-vale-of-glamorgan-tickets-. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: penarth ramblers explore history nature walk
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityIt was girl power when ten female walkers joined Joy and sheepdog Bracken from Penarth and District Ramblers at Penarth clftop for an . mile walk, with no stiles only gates and which would see them experiencing the weather of all four seasons in one day. They set off on a socially distanced walk in lovely spring sunshine across the old pitch and putt course before joining part of the old railway line, now a walk and cycle way, and heading through a built up area Lavernock Road led them into Cosmeston Country Park.Past the eastern lake with its floating jetty where canoes can be safely launched and making their way through the eastern paddock with its carpet of pretty cowslips, open meadows led them towards Old Cogan Hall Farm, where they deviated into the churchyard of St Peterrsquos for morning break in glorious warm sunshine reminiscent of summer. Admiring the herring bone masonry which dates to Celtic and Saxon times and the ancient yew trees that could even pre-date this lovely old church, which allegedly is the oldest building in Penarth and hearing some of its long and interesting history, it fell into disrepair in the th century. By the th century the ruinous building was a cattle shelter until the latter part of the rsquos when the rd Marquis of Bute was persuaded to pay for its renovation.Mile Road built by the Bute family led them to the western paddock and through the sun-dappled Cogan Wood to re-enter fields where a footbridge led them across the Sully Brook for the short climb up to Home Farm, with its glorious views towards the eastern end of Barry and the surrounding farmland. Exiting through a gate, some road walking in a southerly direction brought them into Sully village and pounding pavements to reach the Jubilee Hall and the cricket field, the full beauty of Sully Bay with its views across the Bristol Channel towards the Somerset coastline and Hayes Point to the west confronted them.     With the wind beginning to pick up they tramped by track and field to the public slipway at Sully beach and stopped for lunch utilising rocks for seating whilst gazing eastwards towards Sully Island and Flat and Steep Holm beyond, as clouds thickened overhead and the temperature dropped making it feel more like autumn.Time to move on along part of the long distance Wales Coast Path, through the playing fields to exit onto Beach Road, following it to the car park of the Captainrsquos We where there were only a few people sitting at outdoor tables for food and drink, not really enjoyable in the cool breeze.The fairly quiet St Maryrsquos Well Bay Road brought them up past The Bay Caravan Park and into fields with growing crops where, without any warning a sudden short sharp shower of rain engulfed the group forcing coats to be swtly donned.Crossing a wooden footbridge into the delightful Lavernock Nature Reserve the grassy path led them into the remains of the WW gun emplacements. Initially in the late rsquos the original Lavernock Gun Battery was built to protect the Bristol and Cardf shipyards and the Bristol Channel, but unfortunately most of the original buildings now lie underneath the caravan park.Being bombarded by a short hail storm whilst moving on through the nature reserve, lovingly cared for by volunteers and passing the man-made pond with its surrounding carpet of bluish violet bugle, a plant which attracts moths, butterflies and bees, before exiting onto Fort Road their route led them past the Marconi Holiday Village and the Church of St Lawrence before heading along the clftop. With thick black clouds heading up the English side of the Bristol Channel, the race was on to get back before the rain hit. As the weather turned wintry and the wind increased, a huge shower of hailstones and heavy rain struck them on the open Penarth clftop soaking them as they made their way back to their start point.You can follow the grouprsquos exploits before, during and after lockdown on Facebook. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: sotm st richard gwyn catholic high school barry
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communitySt Richard GwynCatholic High School, on Argae Lane in Barry, has  pupils currently on roll, with this number increasing to  - the schoolrsquos biggest Year Seven cohort yet.Mr David Blackwell has been head teacher at the school since February , following his role as deputy head for more than four years.Headteacher Mr David BlackwellHe is backed by deputy head Matthew Dunn assistant headteachers Laura Burnettand Amy Leftleyand senior core leader Sharon Macleod.The schoolrsquos last Estyn report was in  ndash the school was rated lsquoadequatersquo overall but with good prospects of improvement.Explaining some of the improvements made since, Mr Blackwell said: ldquoWe have fully embedded the Jesuit Pupil Profile into the le of staff and students."The Jesuit Pupil Profile gives a focus to the citizens that we wish to nurture at SRG. It reminds staff and students that virtues towards the needs of others is paramount to the essence of our humanity."He continued: We have always prioritised wellbeing of our students but over the last two years we have developed a lsquowellbeing progress centre. Support staff have been trained extensively to ensure that all students are ready to learn.ldquoThe wellbeing team are always on hand to assist with the students wellbeing by offering sessions for ELSA, Thrive and Mental Health Wellbeing. We even have two wellbeing dogs that support some of our more vulnerable learners.ldquoWe work very closely with a iety of external agencies to support our students needs to ensure students are engaged and feel safe and secure and able to fulfil their full potential.The school caters to pupils with additional learning needs and to staff wellbeing. Staff at the school have training, progression opportunities, open door policy of support, and clear lines of communication.     ldquoTeaching and learning continues to be our core focus, added Mr Blackwell.ldquoThe  Inspection report praised students at SRG for lsquotheir positive attitude to learningrsquo. We have built upon this and we now offer a Scholarrsquos Programme to prepare students for their education pathway.ldquoWe want to offer students a chance to broaden their educational experience with us. We have broadened our option subjects at KS - we are now able to offer Construction, Health and Social Care and Textiles and Fashion.ldquoWe are committed to the promotion of SRG as a learning organisation. To this end we have entered into an ITE Partnership with Cardf politan University and an alliance with St.Illtydrsquos Catholic Comprehensive in Cardf. It is mutually beneficial since we help develop new teachers into the profession and we are able to utilise educational research to improve standards across both key stages.The Catholic school strives to ensures pupils succeed, while also being good people.ldquoWe aim for our pupils to live by the ethos of our pupil profile which is about virtues to empower them to be a success in le, added Mr Blackwell.ldquoWe are the faith secondary school of the Vale and so provide an excellent secondary education that runs equally alongside our holistic development of our pupils as iniduals and good all round people.The Catholic ethos is embedded into daily le at the school, with morning prayer, virtues-based assemblies, and daily reflection.ldquoAll staff engage in role modelling behaviour that reflects the Catholic virtues of honesty, integrity and forgiveness, added Mr Blackwell.ldquoDuring normal school times Mass is a frequent part of our school le ndash not all pupils come to us with a faith background, but they all appreciate the values that we try to weave into our everyday lives.Along with the schoolrsquos ethical focus St Richard Gwyn Catholic High School has an abundance of extra-curricular activities on offer, including school trips.Sporty youngsters can take part in football, rugby, netball, hockey, tennis, badminton, athletics, cheerleading and street dance. Therersquos also Clwb Cymraeg and an array of creative activities on offer ndash including art club, textiles club, choir, SRG band.Bi-annually the music, drama, and art departments join forces to produce and perform an arts production.St Richard Gwyn Catholic High School strives to form lsquopositive relationshipsrsquo with families and the local community and has a Facebook group regularly updated with video messages from Mr Blackwell and key messages for families.Each year group has a Progress Leader who is a point of contact for families as well as our Wellbeing and Progress Centre who liaises with families on a regular basis. Plus, St Richard Gwyn Catholic High School is in the process of obtaining the Investors in Families , which ndash in a nutshell ndash lsquois a quality mark that recognises the work that schools and other settings undertake with families to improve outcomes for children and young people.rsquoThe school is also lsquoproudrsquo to have worked with numerous charities ndash including fundraising for local food banks and helping Keep Wales Tidy with beach cleans.The school has also adapted a lsquogreatrsquo deal during the coronavirus pandemic ndash with the immediate priority being health and safety such as year group lsquobubblesrsquo, separate lunches, allocated outdoor spaces, regular sanitizing and face coverings.ldquoThe biggest impact, in terms of day to day operation, meant teachers moved more between lessons than students, said Mr Blackwell.ldquoCrucial to adapting to the pandemic was to adoption of online learning. There have been periods of lockdown with no pupils in school as well as fortnightly periods that have required year groups to isolate.He praised the training and use of online s as lsquotransformativersquo. and added that - while itrsquos lsquofantasticrsquo to resume in-person learning these changes and developments will continue to improve how the school operates.The school is lsquovery fortunatersquo to have been supported by the local authority to make the best of the buildings they have, but the school is awaiting progress on a new build under the st Century schools programme, financed by Welsh Government.ldquoWe firmly believe that what goes on inside school is more important than the way the building looks externally, said Mr Blackwell.ldquoWe have amazing staff who work exceptionally hard to make the best of the facilities we have, all pupils who come to us get a great educational experience.ldquoHowever, we are still awaiting progress on a new build. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. It was used for dances during the second world war, and a nightclub in the s and s. The building fell into disrepair about a decade ago, but a charity called Penarth Arts and Craft Limited spent lottery funding on renovation.Then the pavilion reopened in  as an arts and culture venue with a cinema, exhibition space, meeting rooms and a cafe. However, the charity later struggled with directors leaving and challenging trading conditions, particularly during the coronavirus pandemic.MORE NEWS:Towards the end of last year, the charity entered discussions with the Vale council and the National Lottery about what could be done. The council then took over control of the building last February, and asked the public for suggestions about how the pavilion should be used.A new cafe has opened in the pavilion, run by the councilrsquos armrsquosBig Fresh Catering Company. All profits from this company are put into providing healthy meals for schools.Essential repairs and maintenance have also been carried out on the building, including replacing the air conditioning repairing the lighting, fire doors, and gas boilers and testing the lt, water hygiene, and fire alarms. Initial works have cost about pound,.     The kitchen has also seen repairs and cleaning outside walls have been cleaned and the decking jet washed tables have been sanded and resealed and a broken window was replaced. Public wi has been improved and the cinema projector has been maintained.The childrenrsquos section of Penarth Library will temporarily be relocated to the pavilion. The section is currently not well ventilated enough to be Covid-secure, but it should be in the pavilion. Regular activities like Story Time will be held at the pavilion.The building could also soon host live music and a bar, as the council is applying for licences to play music and serve alcohol there.More than , people responded to a public consultation on what should happen next with the building from March  until April . Most would like to see included in the plans a cinema, cafe, bar or street food space also with live music, theatre and comedy shows.Some respondents suggested the pavilion could run similar to Chapter Arts in Cardf. Council bosses are now drawing up a business plan which should include firmer details on what will happen next to the building. The upper with decked sun terrace and raised border with steps falling to a lower lawn.The rear of the property accommodates a substantial patio with sunny south westerly aspect and arched gateway which leads to a garden room.This property is on the market with Burnett Davies with Easton, Vale of Glamorgan. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityIt comes as the UK Government is set to outline its plan to level up the country, though anti-poverty charity the Joseph Rowntree Foundation said it must improve on its "piecemeal" attempts so far.A survey by the think tank Demos asked , adults in parliamentary constituencies across Great Britain to choose which one of nine issues most urgently needs improving in their local area.In Cardf South and Penarth, .#% of residents chose good local shops.This was followed by good transport services , and housing that suits their needs .Mel Grfin, owner of Grfin Books, said she was ldquosurprised at these figures.ldquoIn Penarth I think wersquore very fortunate to have a wide range of excellent independent shops as well as a good representation of national chains, she added.ldquoYou can get pretty much anything you need in the town itself without the need to travel into Cardf. Despite the challenges of the past year, wersquove all hung in there, and I believe there are currently no empty shops in the town centre which is a great indicator for the future.Angelina Hall of Penarth Business Group added: ldquoIf we offer a good mix of hospitality, retail and services, we will ensure our High Street can prosper, attracting both locals and visitors.MORE NEWS:"Whilst City Centres have seen punishing closures leaving huge gaps in their offering, Penarth businesses have worked hard to ersy and adapt in a challenging economic climate.The most pressing issue across Britain was also shops, followed by good transport and jobs.Demos said prioritising retailers was particularly prevalent in more built-up areas, while rural communities were more likely to see a lack of quality transport as a problem.     The think-tank has urged the Government to reflect on its research as it considers how best to spend the pound. billion earmarked for a levelling-up fund to reduce inequality across the UK.In Cardf South and Penarth, an estimated % of residents think that the provision of facilities they consider most important is nearer to bad than good ndash compared to the national average of %.The Centre for Cities said the main challenge facing many urban areas is the comparatively low education levels among the workforce, meaning well-paid jobs are scarce and wages lower.A Skills and Post- Education Bill ndash new legislation aimed at reforming education for older teenagers and adults ndash was also announced in the Queens Speech.But the Centre for Cities said the Government must "make good on its promises" to improve education and training opportunitiesit is to level up less prosperous parts of the country.Andrew Carter, the think tanks chief executive, said: "Lower wages mean less disposable income to spend in local shops and other amenities. As a result many struggle and close ndash creating a general feeling of being left behind."The Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government said the Levelling Up Fund will regenerate high streets, upgrade local transport and invest in cultural assets.A spokeswoman added: ldquoOur Plan for Jobs will create opportunities for people of all ages wherever they live by boosting skills and giving them the best possible chance of getting a job." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: bethan roper inquest jury hears friends
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityBethan Roper, , suffered fatal head injuries while a passenger on the Great Western Railwaytravelling at around mph.Miss Roper, of Penarth, was ing home to South Wales from a day out with friends Christmas shopping in Bath.Avon Coronerrsquos Court heard Miss Roper and her three friends, Elizabeth Winstone Evans, Chanelle Hagland and Madeleine Owens, had boarded the train at Bath Spa station on the evening of December , .The GWR London Paddington to Exeter service was using carriages fitted with droplight windows to enable passengers to use the handle on the outside when they needed to leave the train at the .Investigators told the inquest that the warning label above the window, a yellow sticker with the words: lsquoCaution do not lean out of window when train is movingrsquo, was not a sufficient deterrent.Miss Roper was fatally injured just a few minutes after the train left Bath when her head was struck by an ash tree branch growing on land adjacent to the line.PC Kate Aldred, of British Transport Police, spoke with Miss Hagland when the train arrived at Bristol Temple Meads station shortly after the incident and made written notes of the conversation.ldquoThe train had been travelling five or six minutes when Miss Evans opened the pulldown window of the door, Pc Aldred said.ldquoMiss Evans leant her head out of the window very slightly for about  seconds and then said something like, lsquoGirls try thisrsquo.ldquoMiss Evans put her head back inside the carriage and then Miss Roper has immediately stepped forward and put her head right out of the window.ldquoMiss Hagland was sat on the floor close to Miss Roperrsquos legs.ldquoMiss Roperrsquos head must only have been out for five seconds when Miss Hagland heard the sound of an impact.ldquoMiss Roper fell backwards towards Miss Hagland and caught Miss Roper.     ldquoMiss Roper then fell forwards and slumped onto the floor.Later, Miss Hagland told police in a statement that by the time they caught the train they were not ldquodrunk or disorderly.ldquoWersquove all had a quite a few drinks but we are used to drinking like that.ldquoWe had all sobered up by then and drunk ourselves sober, she told officers.Describing the minutes before the incident, Miss Hagland said they were all in the vestibule area of the train as it was busy and her friend Miss Evans pulled down the window of the door as she was hot.ldquoLizzy leant her head out of the window just slightly and her hair was blowing, Miss Hagland said.ldquoI think Lizzy was hot and I didnrsquot even know those windows go down.ldquoI heard Lizzy say, lsquolook at this girlsrsquo and when she pulled in Beth charged over and did exactly the same thing and she put her head out just a little bit more than Lizzy did.ldquoFrom what I can remember the shoulders were still in the carriage.ldquoI was just about to stand up when the branch hit her head.ldquoIt was pretty much straight awayhellip five seconds.ldquoShe kind of took two steps back and stumbled and fell right into me and fell forward.A post-mortem examination found Miss Roper had died from head injuries.Toxicology tests found she had a blood alcohol level of mg in ml of blood, meaning she was nearly twice the drink drive limit.Miss Roper worked for the Welsh Refugee Council charity and was chairwoman of Young Socialists Cardf.The hearing continues. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url title: blockbuster movies ready for omniplex reopening
story: Traffic Attendants back on streets next week   Toddler, who died in tragic incident, is named locallyNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoHomes and GardensLestyleCarsHomes and GardensPublic NoticesAdvertise My BusinessNewsPeopleBlockbuster movies ready for Omniplex reopeningMovie buffs will be delighted that the local Omniplex chain is all set to reopen to the public next Monday - pending the easing of Lockdown restrictions.By Carmel RobinsonMonday, th May , : pm  "       "  Ready to roll out the reels, the Omniplex Cinemas are awaiting official confirmation from the NI Executive - which is due on Thursday .The cinema chain plans to begin its phased reopening of five sites, with Omniplex Craigavon Lisburn, Dundonald, Newry and Bangor welcoming customers back to a covid safe way from this date. Eight more Omniplex locations across the country are ready to resume screening from Friday th May marking the first time this year for avid movie goers to enjoy the big screen experience. ]]Craigavon Omniplex.The cinema chain – the largest in NI, closed all of its venues on December , , when all areas of the UK and Ireland were under pandemic restrictions. Paul John Anderson, Director of Omniplex Cinemas said: “We are thrilled to finally be welcoming back cinema goers for the first time this year. We strongly believe in the power of escapism that a couple of hours spent at the cinema provides and we are looking forward to opening our doors for the ultimate big screen experience. We have worked hard over the last year to ensure our customers can enjoy the magic of cinema once again. We continue to follow public health advice and the safety of our team and customers remains of utmost importance.” Safety measures will include limited capacity m distance between parties for social distancing requirements face coverings to be worn by staff and audiences when moving within cinema buildings and staggered showtimes to name a few. Omniplex Cinemas will also be operating enhanced online booking to make the visit as contactless as possible with increased cleaning regimes and hand sanitising stations in every foyer. Visitors will be expected to wear face masks but will be allowed to remove them when seated in auditoriums for eating or drinking. Paul added: “It’s been a long and dficult year for us all with restrictions affecting our daily lives. We know that our audiences are eager to get back to the big screen and we cannot wait to see people experiencing the cinema once again.” Several film studios had paused the release of their ‘tentpole’ blockbusters in , opting for release dates in the latter half of . From th May, film fans can enjoy films including Peter Rabbit , voiced by stars including James Corden and Margot Robbie and much-anticipated horror film The Conjuring . A raft of blockbuster films is set to be released in this summer with Marvel releasing the much-delayed Black Widow on th July. DC Comics will play to a similar field of movie goers with the release of The Suicide Squad on th August. The ninth instalment of Fast and Furious will come to cinema screens across NI on th July this year. The th James Bond will also grace the movie screens with No Time to Die featuring Daniel Craig as  expected to come out on th September in the UK and Ireland. Tickets are on sale now in advance of these reopening dates at www.omniplex.ie. The remaining sites in Derry, Belfast, Antrim, Carrickfergus, Omagh, Downpatrick, Banbridge and Dungannon will open again from Friday th May. Omniplex is the largest cinema chain in Ireland, with over  screens in  locations.
